The text further states that Zhang Liang’s original teachers were the Four Whiteheads—Master Luli, Qi Liji, and their companions—all of whom were immortals. Liang received from them their divine methods in full. Though later compelled by Empress Lü to eat and drink, he soon resumed his cultivation of the immortal Dao, secretly transcending the world. Yet the world remained unaware, and so it was said that he had died. According to Kong Anguo’s account, then, Liang had indeed attained immortality.

Moreover, the Han Chancellor Zhang Cang happened upon a minor technique: by suckling a woman’s milk, he lived to one hundred and eighty years—three times the ordinary lifespan. This was but a shallow practice of the Way, yet even so, it granted him such longevity. How much more, then, might one achieve through the full mastery of secret and wondrous arts? How could one not attain immortality? This account appears in the *Book of Han* and is no empty claim.

The *Baopuzi* states: "Ingesting elixirs is the foundation of longevity, but if one can also practice *qi*-circulation, the benefits come far more swiftly. Even without elixirs, if one cultivates *qi* to its fullest principle, one may yet live for several centuries. However, one must also master the arts of the bedchamber. Why? Without knowledge of yin-yang techniques, repeated exhaustion will cause harm, and *qi*-circulation will prove difficult to sustain. Man dwells within *qi*, and *qi* dwells within man. From heaven and earth to the myriad things, nothing exists without *qi* to give it life. Those skilled in *qi*-circulation nurture the body within and repel evil without, though the common people use it daily without awareness.

In Wu and Yue, there exists a method of incantatory prayer with proven efficacy, relying on the abundance of *qi*. Those who master it may enter the heart of great plagues, sharing a bed with the sick without falling ill. They may lead dozens of followers, all rendered fearless. This is *qi* warding off heavenly disasters. When malevolent spirits or mountain demons invade a household—hurling tiles and stones, setting fires to homes, appearing in visible forms, or merely speaking in disembodied voices—adepts of *qi*-incantation can suppress them instantly. This is *qi* restraining ghosts and gods.

In mountain forests thick with poisonous vipers and venomous creatures, ordinary travelers cannot pass without harm. Yet those skilled in *qi*-incantation can shield an area spanning dozens of *li*, ensuring their companions remain unharmed. They can also subdue tigers, leopards, snakes, and wasps, rendering them docile and unable to rise. With *qi*, they can staunch bleeding from wounds, mend broken bones, and rejoin severed sinews. They can render blades harmless, walking upon them unscathed or making them impervious to thrusts. If one is bitten by a venomous serpent, *qi*-incantation brings instant healing.

In recent times, Zuo Ci, Zhao Ming, and others have used *qi* to make water flow backward for one or two *zhang*. They have kindled fires atop thatched roofs to cook meals without burning the thatch. They have driven large nails seven or eight *cun* into pillars, then blown upon them with *qi* to make the nails spring out. They have subdued boiling water, tossing in over a hundred coins and allowing a man to scoop them out barehanded without scalding. They have exposed water to the open air in freezing weather without it turning to ice. They have prevented all cooking fires within a *li* from properly steaming food. They have silenced dogs, rendering them unable to bark.

Once, when the state of Wu sent General He to suppress mountain bandits, the rebels included a skilled *qi*-incantator. Whenever battle was joined, the government troops found their blades and swords impossible to draw, and their arrows turned back upon them, bringing constant defeat. General He, a man of keen intelligence, devised a plan: "I have heard that edged weapons and venomous creatures can be restrained by *qi*, but objects without edges or venom cannot. If their adept can bind our weapons, he surely cannot bind edgeless things." He then had many sturdy wooden clubs made and selected five thousand elite soldiers of exceptional strength to lead the assault. When they charged the bandits, the rebels relied on their adept’s powers and were wholly unprepared. The government troops struck with their clubs, crushing the enemy. The adept’s *qi* proved ineffective, and the slaughter numbered in the tens of thousands.

*Qi* issues from the body, and its effects are as wondrous as these. Why doubt that it can enable grain-abstention, cure illness, prolong life, and nurture one’s nature?

Zhongchang Gongli, a man of penetrating insight, wrote in his *Changyan*: "Circulating *qi* can eliminate hunger and illness. At first, I did not believe it, but upon witnessing its practice, I saw that it was indeed so. The methods of nurturing one’s nature are this simple, yet I have not mastered them. Is it not because my mind is distracted by worldly affairs and my thoughts consumed by mundane concerns? Others who fail to achieve this must share the same affliction.

Long ago, a master who knew the Way of immortality was sought by the Lord of Yan. The envoy failed to learn it before the master died. Enraged, the lord prepared to execute the envoy. A counselor advised: 'There is no greater sorrow than death, no greater urgency than life. If he himself lost his life, how could he have secured immortality for you?' The lord relented. The counselor’s words were well-reasoned. Had the master possessed the Way of immortality—such as the *qi*-circulation methods I have heard of—then his explanation of the master’s death would not necessarily have been ignorant. He simply could not abandon worldly affairs to practice it, and so, though he knew the method, it brought him no benefit. It was not that the Way of immortality did not exist."

The text further relates: "In Mixian County of Henan, there was a diviner named Bu Cheng who had studied the Dao for many years. One day, he bid farewell to his family, took a step, and rose slightly higher with each stride until he vanished into the clouds. This is what is meant by 'lightening the body to soar' and 'ascending to heaven in broad daylight'—the highest attainment of immortality."

Chen Yuanfang and Han Yuanchang, both eminent scholars of Yingchuan, lived near Mixian. Their belief in the existence of immortals stemmed from their fathers and grandfathers having personally witnessed Bu Cheng’s ascension. This, then, is yet another proof of immortality.

chunks.original_text: 卷六·微旨 抱朴子曰：“余闻归同契合者，则不言而信着； 途殊别务者，虽忠告而见疑。 夫寻常咫尺之近理，人间取舍之细事，沈浮过於金羽，皂白分於粉墨，而抱惑之士，犹多不辨焉，岂况说之以世道之外，示之以至微之旨，大而笑之，其来久矣，岂独今哉？ 夫明之所及，虽玄阴幽夜之地，豪厘芒发之物，不以为难见。 苟所不逮者，虽日月丽天之照灼，嵩岱干云之峻峭，犹不能察焉。 黄老玄圣，深识独见，开秘文於名山，受仙经於神人，蹶埃尘以遣累，凌大遐以高跻，金石不能与之齐坚，龟鹤不足与之等寿，念有志於将来，愍信者之无文，垂以方法，炳然着明，小修则小得，大为则大验。 然而浅见之徒，区区所守，甘於荼蓼而不识台蜜，酣於醨酪而不赏醇醪。 知好生而不知有养生之道，知畏死而不信有不死之法，知饮食过度之畜疾病，而不能节肥甘於其口也。 知极情恣欲之致枯损，而不知割怀於所欲也。 余虽言神仙之可得，安能令其信乎？ ” 或人难曰：“子体无参午达理，奇毛通骨，年非安期彭祖多历之寿，目不接见神仙，耳不独闻异说，何以知长生之可获，养性之有征哉？ 若觉玄妙於心得，运逸鉴於独见，所未敢许也。 夫衣无蔽肤之具，资无谋夕之储，而高谈陶朱之术，自同猗顿之策，取讥论者，其理必也。 抱痼疾而言精和鹊之技，屡奔北而称究孙吴之算，人不信者，以无效也。 ”余答曰：“夫寸鮹泛迹滥水之中，则谓天下无四海之广也。 芒蝎宛转果核之内，则谓八极之界尽於兹也。 虽告之以无涯之浩汗，语之以宇宙之恢阔，以为空言，必不肯信也。 若令吾眼有方瞳，耳长出顶，亦将控飞龙而驾庆云，凌流电而造倒景，子又将安得而诘我。 设令见我，又将呼为天神地祇异类之人，岂谓我为学之所致哉？ 姑聊以先觉挽引同志，岂强令吾子之徒，皆信之哉？ 若令家户有仙人，属目比肩，吾子虽蔽，亦将不疑。 但彼人之道成，则蹈青霄而游紫极，自非通灵，莫之见闻，吾子必为无耳。 世人信其臆断，仗其短见，自谓所度，事无差错，习乎所致，怪乎所希，提耳指掌，终於不悟，其来尚矣，岂独今哉？ ” 或曰：“屡承嘉谈，足以不疑於有仙矣，但更自嫌於不能为耳。 敢问更有要道，可得单行者否？ ”抱朴子曰：“凡学道当阶浅以涉深，由易以及难，志诚坚果，无所不济，疑则无功，非一事也。 夫根荄不洞地，而求柯条干云，渊源不泓窈，而求汤流万里者，未之有也。 是故非积善阴德，不足以感神明； 非诚心款契，不足以结师友； 非功劳不足以论大试； 又未遇明师而求要道，未可得也。 九丹金液，最是仙主。 然事大费重，不可卒办也。 宝精爱炁，最其急也，并将服小药以延年命，学近术以辟邪恶，乃可渐阶精微矣。 ” 或曰：“方术繁多，诚难精备，除置金丹，其馀可修，何者为善？ ”抱朴子曰：“若未得其至要之大者，则其小者不可不广知也。 盖藉众术之共成长生也。 大而谕之，犹世主之治国焉，文武礼律，无一不可也。 小而谕之，犹工匠之为车焉，辕罔轴辖，莫或应亏也。 所为术者，内修形神，使延年愈疾，外攘邪恶，使祸害不干，比之琴瑟，不可以孑弦求五音也，方之甲胄，不可以一札待锋刃也。
chunks.translated_text:
**Scroll Six: Subtle Principles**

The Master of Embracing Simplicity said: "I have heard that those who share the same bond and purpose require no words to establish trust, while those who follow divergent paths and pursuits, though offered loyal counsel, will still harbor doubt. Even in matters of ordinary understanding—trivial affairs of human choice, where gain and loss outweigh gold and feathers, and black and white are as distinct as ink and powder—those burdened by confusion often fail to discern them. How much more so when one speaks of what lies beyond the world’s ways, revealing the most subtle principles? To mock such truths is an ancient habit—how could it be unique to our time?

What the eye of understanding can perceive, even in the darkest recesses of midnight or the most minute objects, presents no difficulty in seeing. Yet where understanding does not reach, even the radiance of the sun and moon illuminating the heavens or the towering heights of Mount Song and Mount Tai remain beyond its grasp. The profound sages of the Yellow Emperor and Laozi, with their deep insight and unique vision, unlocked secret texts in the sacred mountains and received the immortal scriptures from divine beings. They cast off the dust of the world to shed its burdens, soaring to distant heights and ascending beyond the ordinary. Neither metal nor stone can match their firmness, nor tortoises nor cranes rival their longevity. Moved by compassion for those of future generations who aspire to the Way yet lack guidance, they left behind methods, clearly and brilliantly set forth: small efforts yield small results, great endeavors bring great verification.

Yet those of shallow perception cling stubbornly to their limited views, content with bitterness like wormwood and smartweed, unaware of the sweetness of honey; drunk on thin wine, they fail to appreciate fine liquor. They know the value of life but not the Way of nurturing it; they fear death but do not believe in the methods of transcending it. They recognize that excess in food and drink breeds illness yet cannot restrain their indulgence in rich flavors. They understand that unrestrained desires lead to depletion and harm yet cannot sever their attachments. Though I speak of the attainability of immortality, how can I make them believe?"

Someone objected: "Your body lacks the extraordinary marks of wisdom—no intersecting veins or penetrating bones. Your years do not match the longevity of Anqi Sheng or Peng Zu. Your eyes have not beheld immortals, nor have your ears alone heard their teachings. How then do you know that long life can be attained or that the cultivation of nature bears proof? If you claim to perceive the profound through inner realization or to wield discernment through solitary insight, I cannot accept it. One who lacks even the means to cover his skin or secure his next meal yet boasts of the strategies of Tao Zhu or compares himself to Yi Dun invites ridicule—this is only natural. To speak of Bian Que’s healing arts while afflicted by chronic illness, or to claim mastery of Sun and Wu’s tactics after repeated defeats, is to be met with disbelief, for there is no evidence to support it."

I replied: "A minnow drifting in a puddle would claim there are no vast seas. An ant writhing within a fruit pit would assert that the boundaries of the world end there. Though told of boundless oceans or the expanse of the cosmos, it would dismiss such words as empty talk and refuse to believe. If my eyes had square pupils and my ears extended above my head, I would ride flying dragons and mount auspicious clouds, outpace lightning and ascend to the inverted heavens—how then could you question me? Even if you saw me, you would call me a celestial spirit or a divine being, not one who had attained such heights through study. I merely seek to guide those of like mind with the insights of an early awakening—how could I force all of your kind to believe? If every household had an immortal, visible at every turn, even you, though blind, would not doubt. But when such individuals achieve the Dao, they tread the azure heavens and wander the purple pole. Unless one possesses spiritual communion, they remain unseen and unheard—you would surely claim they do not exist.

People trust their own conjectures and rely on their narrow vision, believing their judgments infallible. What they are accustomed to, they accept; what they rarely encounter, they find strange. Though you pull their ears and point to their palms, they remain unmoved. This has been the case for ages—how could it be unique to our time?"

Another asked: "Having heard your excellent discourse, I no longer doubt the existence of immortals. My only regret is that I cannot become one myself. Might there be an essential method, something that can be practiced alone?"

The Master of Embracing Simplicity said: "In learning the Dao, one must progress from the shallow to the deep, from the easy to the difficult. With unwavering resolve and determination, nothing is unattainable. Doubt yields no success—this is no trivial matter. Just as roots that do not penetrate the earth cannot produce towering branches, or shallow springs cannot give rise to rivers flowing a thousand miles, so too is it impossible to achieve greatness without foundation.

Thus, without accumulating hidden virtues and good deeds, one cannot move the divine; without sincere devotion and mutual affinity, one cannot form bonds with teachers and friends; without meritorious deeds, one cannot undertake great trials. Moreover, without encountering an enlightened teacher, the essential Way cannot be obtained. The Nine Elixirs and Golden Liquor are the foremost methods of immortality, yet their preparation requires great expense and cannot be swiftly accomplished. Preserving essence and cherishing qi are the most urgent tasks. One should also ingest minor medicines to prolong life and study lesser arts to ward off evil and misfortune—only then can one gradually ascend to the subtlest principles."

Another asked: "The methods are numerous and difficult to master in full. Setting aside the Golden Elixir, what other practices are worth pursuing? Which are the best?"

The Master of Embracing Simplicity said: "If one has not yet grasped the greatest essentials, the lesser methods cannot be neglected. For it is through the convergence of many arts that long life is achieved. To illustrate with a grand analogy: it is like a ruler governing a state—civil and martial arts, rites and laws, none can be dispensed with. To illustrate with a smaller analogy: it is like a craftsman building a chariot—shafts, wheels, axles, and linchpins, none can be lacking.

The methods serve to cultivate both body and spirit internally, prolonging life and curing illness, and to repel evil and misfortune externally, preventing calamity from encroaching. Compared to a zither, one cannot produce the five notes with a single string; compared to armor, one cannot withstand blades with a single plate."

chunks.original_text: 何者，五音合用不可阙，而锋刃所集不可少也。 凡养生者，欲令多闻而体要，博见而善择，偏修一事，不足必赖也。 又患好事之徒，各仗其所长，知玄素之术者，则曰唯房中之术，可以度世矣； 明吐纳之道者，则曰唯行气可以延年矣； 知屈伸之法者，则曰唯导引可以难老矣； 知草木之方者，则曰唯药饵可以无穷矣； 学道之不成就，由乎偏枯之若此也。 浅见之家，偶知一事，便言已足，而不识真者，虽得善方，犹更求无已，以消工弃日，而所施用，意无一定，此皆两有所失者也。 或本性戆钝，所知殊尚浅近，便强入名山，履冒毒螫，屡被中伤，耻复求还。 或为虎狼所食，或为魍魉所杀，或饿而无绝谷之方，寒而无自温之法，死於崖谷，不亦愚哉？ 夫务学不如择师，师所闻素狭，又不尽情以教之，因告云，为道不在多也。 夫为道不在多，自为已有金丹至要，可不用馀耳。 然此事知之者甚希，宁可虚待不必之大事，而不修交益之小术乎？ 譬犹作家，云不事用他物者，盖谓有金银珠玉，在乎掌握怀抱之中，足以供累世之费者耳。 苟其无此，何可不广播百谷，多储果疏乎？ 是以断谷辟兵，厌劾鬼魅，禁御百毒，治救众疾，入山则使猛兽不犯，涉水则令蛟龙不害，经瘟疫则不畏，遇急难则隐形，此皆小事，而不可不知，况过此者，何可不闻乎？ ” 或曰：“敢问欲修长生之道，何所禁忌？ ”抱朴子曰：“禁忌之至急，在不伤不损而已。 按易内戒及赤松子经及河图记命符皆云，天地有司过之神，随人所犯轻重，以夺其算，算减则人贫耗疾病，屡逢忧患，算尽则人死，诸应夺算者有数百事，不可具论。 又言身中有三尸，三尸之为物，虽无形而实魂灵鬼神之属也。 欲使人早死，此尸当得作鬼，自放纵游行，享人祭酹。 是以每到庚申之日，辄上天白司命，道人所为过失。 又月晦之夜，灶神亦上天白人罪状。 大者夺纪。 纪者，三百日也。 小者夺算。 算者，三日也。 吾亦未能审此事之有无也。 然天道邈远，鬼神难明。 赵简子秦穆公皆亲受金策於上帝，有土地之明征。 山川草木，井灶洿池，犹皆有精气； 人身之中，亦有魂魄； 况天地为物之至大者，於理当有精神，有精神则宜赏善而罚恶，但其体大而网疏，不必机发而响应耳。 然览诸道戒，无不云欲求长生者，必欲积善立功，慈心於物，恕己及人，仁逮昆虫，乐人之吉，愍人之苦，周人之急，救人之穷，手不伤生，口不劝祸，见人之得如己之得，见人之失如己之失，不自贵，不自誉，不嫉妒胜己，不佞谄阴贼，如此乃为有德，受福於天，所作必成，求仙可冀也。 若乃憎善好杀，口是心非，背向异辞，反戾直正，虐害其下，欺罔其上，叛其所事，受恩不感，弄法受赂，纵曲枉直，废公为私，刑加无辜，破人之家，收人之宝，害人之身，取人之位，侵克贤者，诛戮降伏，谤讪仙圣，伤残道士，弹射飞鸟，刳胎破卵，春夏燎猎，骂詈神灵，教人为恶，蔽人之善，危人自安，佻人自功，坏人佳事，夺人所爱，离人骨肉，辱人求胜，取人长钱，还人短陌，决放水火，以术害人，迫胁尪弱，以恶易好，强取强求，掳掠致富，不公不平，淫佚倾邪，凌孤暴寡，拾遗取施，欺绐诳诈，好说人私，持人短长，牵天援地，咒诅求直，假借不还，换贷不偿，求欲无已，憎拒忠信，不顺上命，不敬所师，笑人作善，败人苗稼，损人器物，以穷人用，以不清洁饮饲他人，轻秤小斗，狭幅短度，以伪杂真，采取奸利，诱人取物，越井跨灶，晦歌朔哭。

What is more, the five notes must be used in concert and none may be omitted, just as no part may be lacking where blades converge. In all matters of nurturing life, one must seek extensive knowledge while grasping the essentials, observe broadly and choose wisely—relying solely on one method is never sufficient. Yet there are those who, fond of novelty, cling to their own strengths: those versed in the arts of *xuan* and *su* claim only the bedroom arts can transcend the world; those who understand the Dao of exhalation and inhalation assert that only qi-cultivation can prolong life; those who know the methods of flexion and extension declare that only *daoyin* can forestall old age; those who know the remedies of herbs and trees insist that only medicinal tonics can ensure boundless vitality. The failure of Daoist cultivation stems precisely from such one-sidedness.

Those of shallow vision, having stumbled upon a single method, claim it is enough, yet lacking true discernment, they may chance upon an excellent technique but still seek endlessly, wasting time and effort, their practice ever shifting without constancy—both approaches are equally misguided. Some, by nature dull and limited in understanding, rashly enter the famous mountains, braving venomous stings and bites, repeatedly harmed yet too ashamed to return. Some are devoured by tigers and wolves, some slain by mountain spirits, some starve for lack of grain-cessation methods, some freeze for want of self-warming techniques, dying in ravines and gorges—is this not sheer folly?

In the pursuit of learning, choosing the right teacher is more crucial than mere diligence. If the teacher’s knowledge is narrow and they withhold full instruction, they may claim, "The Dao does not lie in quantity." Indeed, if one possesses the supreme essential of the Golden Elixir, other methods may be unnecessary. Yet such knowledge is exceedingly rare—how can one idly await an uncertain great attainment while neglecting the small arts that bring mutual benefit? It is like a household that scorns all other goods, claiming it needs nothing else—if it truly holds gold, silver, pearls, and jade in its grasp, enough to sustain generations, then perhaps. But lacking such wealth, how can one not cultivate a hundred grains, store abundant fruits and vegetables?

Thus, grain-cessation, evading weapons, suppressing and expelling ghosts and demons, warding off poisons, curing illnesses, entering mountains without fear of beasts, crossing waters unharmed by dragons, surviving plagues unscathed, concealing oneself in peril—these are minor arts, yet indispensable. How much more should one seek what lies beyond them?

Someone asked, "May I inquire about the prohibitions and taboos for those who cultivate the Dao of long life?"

Holding Simplicity replied: "The most urgent prohibitions lie in avoiding harm and injury. According to the *Yi’s* inner admonitions, the *Scripture of Red Pine*, and the *River Chart’s* records of fate and talismans, heaven and earth have spirits that oversee transgressions, deducting from one’s allotted lifespan according to the severity of the offense. When lifespan is diminished, one suffers poverty, illness, and repeated misfortunes; when it is exhausted, one dies. There are hundreds of actions that incur such deductions—it would be impossible to enumerate them all.

It is also said that within the body dwell the Three Corpses, formless yet akin to spirits, ghosts, and numinous beings. They desire a person’s early death so they may become ghosts themselves, roaming freely to enjoy sacrificial offerings. Thus, on every *gengshen* day, they ascend to heaven to report one’s transgressions to the Controller of Fate. On the last night of each lunar month, the Stove God likewise ascends to report one’s sins. Grave offenses deduct a *ji* (three hundred days), while lesser ones deduct a *suan* (three days). I cannot vouch for the truth of these matters, for the Dao of heaven is distant, and ghosts and spirits are hard to fathom.

Yet Zhao Jianzi and Duke Mu of Qin both received golden decrees from the Supreme Emperor, with clear evidence in their lands. Even mountains, rivers, grasses, trees, wells, stoves, ditches, and ponds possess vital spirits—how much more so the human body, which contains hun and po? Heaven and earth, being the greatest of all things, must logically possess spirit; if they possess spirit, they should reward good and punish evil. However, their vastness makes their net loose, so their responses need not be immediate.

Nevertheless, all Daoist admonitions agree: those who seek long life must accumulate goodness, establish merit, be compassionate toward all things, extend empathy to others, show kindness even to insects, rejoice in others’ good fortune, pity others’ suffering, aid those in distress, rescue those in dire straits, refrain from harming living beings, avoid inciting misfortune, regard others’ gains as one’s own, view others’ losses as one’s own, avoid self-aggrandizement or self-praise, neither envy nor flatter, nor harbor malice—only then does one possess virtue and receive heaven’s blessings. One’s endeavors will succeed, and the pursuit of immortality may be hoped for.

But those who despise goodness and delight in killing, whose words belie their hearts, who speak differently behind others’ backs, who oppose the upright, oppress their subordinates, deceive their superiors, betray their patrons, show no gratitude for kindness, manipulate laws for bribes, pervert justice, serve private interests, punish the innocent, destroy families, seize treasures, harm others’ bodies, usurp positions, exploit the worthy, execute the submissive, slander immortals and sages, injure Daoist practitioners, shoot birds in flight, disembowel fetuses and crush eggs, hunt in spring and summer, curse spirits, teach others to do evil, conceal others’ virtues, endanger others for self-preservation, claim others’ achievements as their own, sabotage others’ good deeds, seize what others love, sever others’ bonds of kinship, humiliate others to gain advantage, lend at high interest, repay debts with short measures, unleash floods and fires to harm others, coerce the weak, exchange good for bad, take by force, plunder for wealth, act unjustly, indulge in debauchery and perversion, bully orphans and widows, pocket lost items, deceive and swindle, gossip about others’ secrets, exploit others’ weaknesses, invoke heaven and earth to curse, refuse to repay loans, default on debts, crave endlessly, reject loyalty and honesty, disobey superiors, disrespect teachers, mock those who do good, ruin others’ crops, damage others’ belongings, exploit others’ hardship, feed others unclean food, use false weights and measures, shortchange cloth, mix counterfeits with genuine goods, seek illicit gains, entice others to steal, step over wells or stoves, sing on inauspicious days or wail at the new moon—such actions invite the deduction of lifespan."

chunks.original_text: 凡有一事，辄是一罪，随事轻重，司命夺其算纪，算尽则死。 但有恶心而无恶迹者夺算，若恶事而损於人者夺纪，若算纪未尽而自死者，皆殃及子孙也。 诸横夺人财物者，或计其妻子家口以当填之，以致死丧，但不即至耳。 其恶行若不足以煞其家人者，久久终遭水火劫盗，及遗失器物，或遇县官疾病，自营医药，烹牲祭祀所用之费，要当令足以尽其所取之直也。 故道家言枉煞人者，是以兵刃而更相杀。 其取非义之财，不避怨恨，譬若以漏脯救饥，鸩酒解渴，非不暂饱而死亦及之矣。 其有曾行诸恶事，后自改悔者，若曾枉煞人，则当思救济应死之人以解之。 若妄取人财物，则当思施与贫困以解之。 若以罪加人，则当思荐达贤人以解之。 皆一倍於所为，则可便受吉利，转祸为福之道也。 能尽不犯之，则必延年益寿，学道速成也。 夫天高而听卑，物无不鉴，行善不怠，必得吉报。 羊公积德布施，诣乎皓首，乃受天坠之金。 蔡顺至孝，感神应之。 郭巨煞子为亲，而获铁券之重赐。 然善事难为，恶事易作，而愚人复以项讬伯牛辈，谓天地之不能辨臧否，而不知彼有外名者，未必有内行，有阳誉者不能解阴罪，若以荠麦之生死，而疑阴阳之大气，亦不足以致远也。 盖上士所以密勿而仅免，凡庸所以不得其欲矣。 ” 或曰：“道德未成，又未得绝迹名山，而世不同古，盗贼甚多，将何以却朝夕之患，防无妄之灾乎？ ”抱朴子曰：“常以执日，取六癸上土，以和百叶熏草，以泥门户方一尺，则盗贼不来； 亦可取市南门土，及岁破土，月建土，合和为人，以着朱鸟地，亦压盗也。 有急则入生地而止，无患也。 天下有生地，一州有生地，一郡有生地，一县有生地，一乡有生地，一里有生地，一宅有生地，一房有生地。 ” 或曰：“一房有生地，不亦偪乎？ ”抱朴子曰：“经云，大急之极，隐於车轼。 如此，一车之中，亦有生地，况一房乎？ ” 或曰：“窃闻求生之道，当知二山，不审此山，为何所在，愿垂告悟，以袪其惑。 ”抱朴子曰：“有之，非华霍也，非嵩岱也。 夫太元之山，难知易求，不天不地，不沈不浮，绝险绵邈，{山罪}嵬崎岖，和气絪缊，神意并游，玉井泓邃，灌溉匪休，百二十官，曹府相由，离坎列位，玄芝万株，绛树特生，其宝皆殊，金玉嵯峨，醴泉出隅，还年之士，挹其清流，子能修之，乔松可俦，此一山也。 长谷之山，杳杳巍巍，玄气飘飘，玉液霏霏，金池紫房，在乎其隈，愚人妄往，至皆死归，有道之士，登之不衰，采服黄精，以致天飞，此二山也。 皆古贤之所秘，子精思之。 ”或曰：“愿闻真人守身炼形之术。 ”抱朴子曰：“深哉问也。 夫始青之下月与日，两半同升合成一。 出彼玉池入金室，大如弹丸黄如橘，中有嘉味甘如蜜，子能得之谨勿失。 既往不追身将灭，纯白之气至微密，升於幽关三曲折，中丹煌煌独无匹，立之命门形不卒，渊乎妙矣难致诘。 此先师之口诀，知之者不畏万鬼五兵也。 ”
chunks.translated_text:
For every single transgression, there is a corresponding sin; according to the gravity of the offense, the Controller of Fate deducts from one’s allotted lifespan or destiny. When the lifespan is exhausted, death follows. Even those who harbor evil intentions without acting upon them suffer deductions to their lifespan; those whose evil deeds harm others lose their destiny. If one dies before their lifespan or destiny is fully spent, the misfortune extends to their descendants.

Those who forcibly seize others’ property may have their wives, children, or household members calculated as compensation, leading to their deaths—though not immediately. If their evil deeds are insufficient to claim the lives of their family, they will eventually encounter disasters such as floods, fires, banditry, or the loss of possessions. They may also face official punishments, illness, or incur expenses for medical treatment, sacrificial offerings, or animal slaughter, all of which will inevitably exhaust the value of what they unjustly took.

Thus, Daoist teachings say that those who wrongfully kill others will in turn be slain by blades. Taking wealth through unrighteous means, heedless of resentment, is like using spoiled meat to sate hunger or poisoned wine to quench thirst—though it may temporarily satisfy, death will soon follow.

For those who have committed such evils but later repent, if they have wrongfully killed, they must seek to save those facing death to atone. If they have unjustly taken others’ property, they must give alms to the poor to resolve it. If they have falsely accused others, they must promote and elevate the worthy to undo the harm. In all cases, they must repay double what they took, and only then can they receive blessings, turning misfortune into fortune.

Those who refrain entirely from such transgressions will surely prolong their years, extend their lifespan, and swiftly achieve the Dao. Though heaven is high, it hears the lowly; nothing escapes its scrutiny. Persisting in good deeds ensures auspicious reward. Lord Yang accumulated virtue and practiced generosity until his hair turned white, and was rewarded with gold from heaven. Cai Shun’s utmost filial piety moved the spirits to respond. Guo Ju, who killed his son to care for his mother, received a heavy iron charter of reward.

Yet good deeds are difficult to perform, while evil deeds come easily. Fools, like those who cite Bo Niu’s misfortune, claim that heaven and earth cannot distinguish right from wrong. They do not realize that those with external reputations may lack inner virtue, and public praise cannot absolve hidden sins. To doubt the great qi of yin and yang based on the fleeting life and death of shepherd’s purse and wheat is to fall short of true understanding. Thus, the superior person acts with utmost care and barely escapes harm, while the mediocre fail to attain their desires.”

Someone asked, “Before achieving the Dao or retreating to the mountains, and given that the world today differs from antiquity with its abundance of thieves, how can one ward off daily troubles and prevent unforeseen disasters?”

The Master Who Embraces Simplicity replied, “Regularly on *zhiri* days, take soil from above the sixth *gui* stem, mix it with hundred-leafed mugwort, and plaster a one-foot square on your door—thieves will not come. Alternatively, take soil from the south gate of the market, or from the earth of the year’s broken sector or the month’s dominant sector, shape it into a figure, and place it in the Vermilion Bird direction to suppress thieves. In emergencies, enter a *shengdi* (life-preserving ground) to remain safe. There are *shengdi* in the world, in every province, commandery, county, village, hamlet, residence, and even within a single room.”

Someone asked, “A *shengdi* in a single room—is that not too confined?”

The Master replied, “The scriptures say, ‘In dire straits, hide beneath the carriage crossbar.’ If even a carriage has a *shengdi*, how much more a room?”

Someone asked, “I have heard that to seek longevity, one must know of two mountains. May I inquire where these mountains are located? I humbly seek your enlightenment to dispel my confusion.”

The Master replied, “They exist, but they are neither Mount Hua nor Mount Tai. The Mountain of the Great Origin is difficult to know yet easy to seek—neither celestial nor terrestrial, neither submerged nor floating. Its perilous paths stretch endlessly, rugged and winding. Harmonious qi intermingles, and divine intent roams freely. Jade wells run deep, their waters ceaselessly irrigating. One hundred twenty offices and bureaus align in succession. The positions of *li* and *kan* are arrayed, with ten thousand stalks of dark mushrooms. Crimson trees grow uniquely, their treasures unparalleled—gold and jade towering. Sweet springs emerge from the corners, and those who drink their pure flow become ageless. If you cultivate this, you may join the ranks of the pine and cypress. This is the first mountain.

The Mountain of the Long Valley stands vast and towering, its dark qi drifting, its jade liquid misting. Golden pools and purple chambers lie hidden in its recesses. Fools who venture there blindly meet only death, but those who possess the Dao ascend without decline. They gather and consume yellow essence, attaining celestial flight. This is the second mountain. Both have been kept secret by the sages of old; ponder them deeply.”

Someone asked, “I wish to hear of the true person’s art of guarding the body and refining the form.”

The Master replied, “A profound question indeed. Beneath the First Green, the moon and sun each contribute half to form a single whole. It emerges from the jade pool and enters the golden chamber, as large as a pellet and as yellow as a tangerine. Within lies a fine flavor, sweet as honey—if you obtain it, guard it well. Once it departs, it cannot be reclaimed, and the body will perish. The pure white qi is most subtle and dense, ascending through the secluded pass in three winding turns. The central cinnabar shines brilliantly, unmatched. Placed at the Gate of Life, the form does not decay. Profound and wondrous, it defies inquiry. This is the oral transmission of my former teacher. Those who know it fear neither the ten thousand ghosts nor the five weapons.”

One asked, “I have heard that those who fully master the arts of the bedchamber may, through this practice alone, attain transcendence and become immortals. They may also avert calamities, absolve transgressions, transform misfortune into fortune, secure promotions in office, and double the profits of merchants. Is this true?”

The Master replied, “Such claims are but the extravagant and deceptive words found in the books of shamans—distortions born of meddlers who embellish and exaggerate until truth is lost. Some are even the fabrications of deceivers, spun to delude the world, conceal their true methods, and solicit offerings, gathering disciples to pursue worldly gain.

The arts of yin and yang may, at best, cure minor ailments or, at least, prevent depletion and exhaustion. Their principles have their limits—how could they lead to transcendence or ward off misfortune and bring fortune? Yet one cannot remain without the union of yin and yang, for to do so invites illness.

If one indulges in unrestrained desire without moderation, it will cut short one’s years. But those skilled in these arts can halt the galloping steed to replenish the brain, return the cinnabar of yin to redden the intestines, gather the jade nectar from the golden pool, and draw the Three and Five to the flowering beam. This allows one to retain a youthful countenance in old age and fulfill the full span of one’s allotted years.

Yet common folk, hearing that the Yellow Emperor ascended to heaven with one thousand two hundred women, assume he attained longevity through this practice alone. They do not know that the Yellow Emperor, beneath Mount Jing and above Lake Ding, refined the Nine Elixirs to completion before riding the dragon to heaven. He may well have had one thousand two hundred women, but this was not the sole path to his transcendence.

Those who consume a thousand medicines and partake of the three sacrificial animals yet remain ignorant of the arts of the bedchamber will gain no benefit. Thus, the ancients, fearing that people would indulge their passions recklessly, spoke of these arts in glowing terms—but one must not believe them entirely.

The Plain Girl and the Dark Maiden likened it to water and fire: both can kill, yet both can also give life, depending on whether one knows how to use them. In general, knowing the essential methods, the more women one engages with, the better. But without understanding the Way, even one or two will hasten death.

The method of Peng Zu contains the most essential teachings. Other texts are overly cumbersome and difficult to practice, yet their benefits do not necessarily match their claims. Few can truly master them. The oral instructions amount to several thousand words. Without this knowledge, even consuming a hundred medicines will not grant longevity.”

Someone asked: "The August Heaven is most divine, and its allotment of fate should be impartial—why then does it grant the longevity of immortality to commoners like Qiao and Song, while the great sages Zhou and Kong are denied even prolonged life?"

Master Embracing Simplicity replied: "The length of a life is truly determined by what one encounters. When one receives *qi* and forms in the womb, each is tied to a particular star. The Dao of Heaven is non-action, letting things follow their nature—without partiality, without favor, without distinction between this and that. If one’s fate is bound to the star of life, that person will necessarily delight in the Dao of immortality. Those who delight in the Dao of immortality will surely attain it if they seek it. If one’s fate is bound to the star of death, that person will not believe in the Dao of immortality. Not believing in it, they will not cultivate its practices. Whether one delights in goodness or not is determined by what one is endowed with; alteration, bestowal, or deprivation are not within Heaven’s power.

"It is like gold and stone melting in the furnace, or earthenware being shaped in the kiln: though their forms are completed through these means, the sharpness or dullness of bronze and iron, the crookedness or straightness of jars and urns, depend on what they encounter—this is no longer the work of the furnace or kiln."

Another objected: "A skilled craftsman’s works all come from his own hands. The divine clarity of Heaven—what is there it cannot do? Yet you claim that human lives each encounter their own fate, not shaped by the August Sky. I am deeply perplexed and cannot accept this."

Master Embracing Simplicity answered: "When the primordial chaos split and the clear and turbid separated, some rose and moved, others descended and stilled—even Heaven and Earth do not know why this is so. The myriad things respond to *qi* and likewise follow their nature. Together with Heaven and Earth, each is a single thing, differing only in whether they form earlier or later, whether their bodies are vast or small. Because Heaven and Earth are great, the myriad things seem small. Because the myriad things are small, Heaven and Earth seem great.

"Moreover, though the belly and back enclose the five viscera, the five viscera are not made by the belly and back. Though skin and flesh wrap the blood and *qi*, the blood and *qi* are not created by the skin and flesh. Though Heaven and Earth contain the myriad things, the myriad things are not made by Heaven and Earth. It is like grasses and trees relying on mountains and forests to flourish, yet mountains and forests do not act upon them; or fish and turtles depending on lakes and marshes to multiply, yet lakes and marshes do not intervene.

"Vulgar people, seeing the vastness of Heaven and Earth and the smallness of the myriad things, say that Heaven and Earth are the parents of the myriad things, and the myriad things are their descendants. But lice are born from me—did I make them? Thus, though lice do not arise without me, I am not their parent, nor are they my descendants. Gnats breed in vinegar, *zhimao* mushrooms grow on wood and stone, leeches thrive in filth, and emerald vines flourish on pine branches—none of these four are crafted by those things. How is the teeming of the myriad things within Heaven and Earth any different?

"Heaven has its sun and moon, cold and heat; humans have their seeing and breathing. Using the distant to analogize the near, and this to infer that, if humans cannot know why their own bodies age, suffer pain, or itch, then Heaven likewise cannot know why its own body waxes or wanes, or why disasters or blessings arise. If humans cannot make their ears and eyes always sharp, or their *ying* and *wei* never obstructed, then Heaven cannot make the sun and moon never eclipse, or the four seasons never lose their order. From this reasoning, the matter of great longevity is truly not in the hands of Heaven and Earth, and whether one becomes immortal or not is decided not by what one encounters.

"Those who give me life are my father, and those who bear me are my mother—yet even they cannot ensure my form is perfectly suited, my appearance lovely, my nature balanced, my wisdom profound, my strength abundant, or my years prolonged. Some are stunted and frail, some dark and ugly, some deaf, blind, stubborn, or crippled. What they receive is not what they desire; what they desire is not what they receive. How much less can the vastness of Heaven and Earth do so? Even parents are distant in comparison.

"Once I have a body, I cannot make it forever strong and unaging, always healthy and free of illness, its joy and anger always fitting, its plans and thoughts never regrettable. Those who bestow *qi* and shape the form are my parents; those who receive and possess it are my own body. Beyond these, nothing is more intimate, nothing has greater control. If even these two cannot benefit or harm me, how can Heaven and Earth have any part in it?

"If all people and things were made by Heaven and Earth, they should all be good and without evil, all complete and without flaw. All living things would thrive, and the osmanthus and poplar would know no autumn’s withering sorrow. You claim that Heaven cannot grant Zhou and Kong the blessing of transcending the world—this only proves that what one is endowed with is natural, not apportioned by Heaven and Earth.

"The virtue of the sage is the highest virtue. If Heaven could bestow such perfect virtue, yet made their knowledge incomplete, their achievements unbuilt, their position not hegemonic, their lifespan not a full century—this would not be evidence of Heaven’s intentional action. The death of the sage is not caused by Heaven, so the birth of the sage is not raised by Heaven either.

"The worthy need not live long, the foolish need not die young. Goodness does not bring near blessings, nor evil near misfortune. Life has no fixed term, death no constant measure. The most virtuous and wise may blossom but bear no fruit, while the mediocre man Dou may live nearly two hundred years. Boniu was stricken with illness, Zixia lost his sight. Robber Zhi was utterly wicked yet lived to white hair, while Zhuang Qiao was extremely evil yet reached yellowed locks. Heaven’s non-action is clear in this."

Someone said: "Confucius said, 'From ancient times, all have died.' Laozi said, 'The immortality of the *xian* can be learned.' The words of the sage are trustworthy and verifiable, while the Daoists’ claims are extravagant and difficult to apply."

Master Embracing Simplicity replied: "Confucius is the sage of the Confucians..."

chunks.original_text: 老子，得道之圣也。 儒教近而易见，故宗之者众焉。 道意远而难识，故达之者寡焉。 道者，万殊之源也。 儒者，大淳之流也。 三皇以往，道治也。 帝王以来，儒教也。 谈者咸知高世之敦朴，而薄季俗之浇散，何独重仲尼而轻老氏乎？ 是玩华藻於木末，而不识所生之有本也。 何异乎贵明珠而贱渊潭，爱和璧而恶荆山，不知渊潭者，明珠之所自出，荆山者，和璧之所由生也。 且夫养性者，道之馀也； 礼乐者，儒之末也。 所以贵儒者，以其移风易俗，不唯揖让与盘旋也。 所以尊道者，以其不言而化行，匪独养生之一事也。 若儒道果有先后，则仲尼未可专信，而老氏未可孤用。 仲尼既敬问伯阳，愿比老彭。 又自以知鱼鸟而不识龙，喻老氏於龙，盖其心服之辞，非空言也。 与颜回所言，瞻之在前，忽然在后，钻之弥坚，仰之弥高，无以异也。 ” 或曰：“仲尼亲见老氏而不从学道，何也？ ”抱朴子曰：“以此观之，益明所禀有自然之命，所尚有不易之性也。 仲尼知老氏玄妙贵异，而不能挹酌清虚，本源大宗，出乎无形之外，入乎至道之内，其所谘受，止於民闲之事而已，安能请求仙法耶？ 忖其用心汲汲，专於教化，不存乎方术也。 仲尼虽圣於世事，而非能沈静玄默，自守无为者也。 故老子戒之曰：良贾深藏若虚，君子盛德若愚，去子之骄气与多欲，态色与淫志，是无益於子之身。 此足以知仲尼不免於俗情，非学仙之人也。 夫栖栖遑遑，务在匡时，仰悲凤鸣，俯叹匏瓜，沽之恐不售，忼慨思执鞭，亦何肯舍经世之功业，而修养生之迂阔哉？ ” 或曰：“儒道之业，孰为难易？ ”抱朴子答曰：“儒者，易中之难也。 道者，难中之易也。 夫弃交游，委妻子，谢荣名，损利禄，割粲烂於其目，抑铿锵於其耳，恬愉静退，独善守己，谤来不戚，誉至不喜，睹贵不欲，居贱不耻，此道家之难也。 出无庆吊之望，入无瞻视之责，不劳神於七经，不运思於律历，意不为推步之苦，心不为艺文之役，众烦既损，和气自益，无为无虑，不怵不惕，此道家之易也，所谓难中之易矣。 夫儒者所修，皆宪章成事，出处有则，语默随时，师则循比屋而可求，书则因解注以释疑，此儒者之易也。 钩深致远，错综典坟，该河洛之籍籍，博百氏之云云，德行积於衡巷，忠贞尽於事君，仰驰神於垂象，俯运思於风云，一事不知，则所为不通，片言不正，则褒贬不分，举趾为世人之所则，动唇为天下之所传，此儒家之难也，所谓易中之难矣。 笃论二者，儒业多难，道家约易，吾以患其难矣，将舍而从其易焉。 世之讥吾者，则比肩皆是也。 可与得意者，则未见其人也。 若同志之人，必存乎将来，则吾亦未谓之为希矣。 ” 或曰：“余阅见知名之高人，洽闻之硕儒，果以穷理尽性，研核有无者多矣，未有言年之可延，仙之可得者也。 先生明不能并日月，思不能出万夫，而据长生之道，未之敢信也。 ”抱朴子曰：“吾庸夫近才，见浅闻寡，岂敢自许以拔群独识，皆胜世人乎？ 顾曾以显而求诸乎隐，以易而得之乎难，校其小验，则知其大效，睹其已然，则明其未试耳。 且夫世之不信天地之有仙者，又未肯规也。 率有经俗之才，当涂之伎，涉览篇籍助教之书，以料人理之近易，辨凡猥之所惑，则谓众之所疑，我能独断之，机兆之未朕，我能先觉之，是我与万物之情，无不尽矣，幽翳冥昧，无不得也。

Laozi is the sage of those who attain the Dao. The Confucian teachings are near and easily seen, so those who follow them are many. The Dao’s meaning is distant and difficult to recognize, so those who grasp it are few. The Dao is the source of the ten thousand differences; Confucianism is a branch of the great purity. Before the Three Sovereigns, the Dao governed. From the rise of emperors and kings, Confucian teachings prevailed. Those who discuss these matters all know the lofty antiquity’s honest simplicity and despise the decadence of later ages—why then do they honor Confucius alone and slight Laozi? This is like admiring the blossoms at the tips of branches while failing to recognize the root from which they grow. How is it different from prizing bright pearls while despising the deep abyss, loving the *he* jade while hating Mount Jing—unaware that the abyss is where bright pearls arise, and Mount Jing is where the *he* jade is born?

Moreover, nurturing one’s nature is but a remnant of the Dao; rites and music are but the fringe of Confucianism. What is valued in Confucianism is its power to transform customs and alter mores—not merely bowing and yielding or pacing in circles. What is revered in the Dao is its silent transformation—not merely the single matter of nurturing life. If Confucianism and the Dao truly had an order of precedence, then Confucius could not be exclusively trusted, nor Laozi employed in isolation.

Confucius himself paid respectful homage to Boyang and wished to be compared to Lao Peng. He also admitted that though he understood fish and birds, he did not know the dragon—and likened Laozi to the dragon. These were words of heartfelt admiration, not empty praise. They differ not at all from what he told Yan Hui: *"Gazing, it is before me; suddenly, it is behind. Boring into it, it grows ever harder; looking up to it, it grows ever higher."*

Someone asked: "Confucius personally met Laozi yet did not study the Dao—why?"

Master Embracing Simplicity replied: "From this, we see all the more clearly that what one is endowed with is a natural mandate, and what one esteems is an unchanging nature. Confucius recognized Laozi’s profound subtlety and exalted strangeness, yet could not draw from the pure and empty, the great origin and fundamental source—emerging beyond formlessness, entering into the supreme Dao. What he sought to learn was limited to matters among the people; how could he have requested the methods of immortality?

I surmise that his heart was wholly absorbed in teaching and transformation, with no thought for esoteric arts. Though Confucius was a sage in worldly affairs, he was not one who could abide in stillness and silence, guarding non-action. Thus Laozi warned him: *'A good merchant stores deeply as if empty; a noble man of great virtue appears foolish. Rid yourself of your prideful air and excessive desires, your affected manner and extravagant ambitions—these bring no benefit to your person.'* This is enough to know that Confucius was not free from worldly passions and was no student of immortality.

Ever restless and hurried, his efforts were devoted to correcting the age. Gazing up, he mourned the phoenix’s cry; looking down, he sighed for the gourd. Fearing his teachings would not sell, he declared with indignation his willingness to hold the whip—how then could he abandon the work of ordering the world to pursue the impractical study of nurturing life?"

Someone asked: "Between the Confucian and Daoist paths, which is more difficult?"

Master Embracing Simplicity answered: "Confucianism is difficulty within ease; the Dao is ease within difficulty. To abandon socializing, forsake wife and children, renounce fame and glory, forgo profit and emolument, turn away from what dazzles the eyes and stifle what delights the ears, to be serene, joyful, and retiring, guarding one’s integrity alone—unmoved by slander, unelated by praise, unmoved by wealth, unashamed by lowliness: this is the difficulty of the Dao. To go out without expectation of condolences or congratulations, to return without obligation to visit or be seen, to spare the mind the labor of the Seven Classics, to free thought from the calculations of calendars and music, to avoid the toil of astronomical reckoning and the servitude of literary arts, to shed the burdens of the many, allowing harmonious qi to flourish naturally—this is the ease of the Dao, what I call ease within difficulty.

As for the Confucian, what he cultivates are all established precedents: conduct has its rules, speech and silence follow the moment. Teachers can be found in every household; books come with commentaries to resolve doubts—this is the ease of Confucianism. To probe the profound and reach the distant, to interweave the classics and ancient texts, to master the clamorous records of the Yellow River and Luo River, to encompass the vast sayings of the hundred schools, to accumulate virtue in humble lanes, to exhaust loyalty and integrity in serving one’s lord, to drive the spirit upward toward celestial signs, to direct thought downward toward wind and clouds—if one matter is unknown, all one does is obstructed; if a single word is amiss, praise and blame are confused. Every step becomes a model for the world; every utterance is transmitted across the land—this is the difficulty of Confucianism, what I call difficulty within ease.

Weighing the two, the Confucian path is mostly difficult, the Daoist path concise and easy. Fearing its difficulty, I will abandon it and follow what is easy. Those who mock me for this are as numerous as the crowd, but those who might share my understanding—I have yet to meet such a person. If like-minded people must await the future, then I do not consider them rare."

Someone said: "I have observed many eminent scholars, widely learned and renowned, who have indeed delved deeply into principle and nature, rigorously examining the boundaries of existence and non-existence—yet none have spoken of extending years or attaining immortality. Though your brilliance does not rival the sun and moon, and your thoughts do not surpass the multitude, I still cannot bring myself to believe in the way of long life."

Master Embracing Simplicity replied: "I am a common man of modest talent, shallow in insight and narrow in learning—how dare I claim to surpass the crowd with unique understanding? Yet I have sought the hidden through what is manifest, obtained the difficult through what is easy. Comparing small proofs, I know the great effects; seeing what has already come to pass, I understand what has yet to be tested.

Moreover, those who do not believe in the immortals of heaven and earth have never even attempted to investigate. Possessing only the talents of the common and the skills of the well-trodden path, they skim through books that aid teaching to assess the near and easy in human affairs, to distinguish what perplexes the vulgar. Then they declare that what the crowd doubts, they alone can decide; that what shows no sign of coming, they alone can foresee. They claim to have exhausted the feelings of all things, to have grasped all that is dark and obscure."

"I say there are no immortals, and immortals must indeed be nonexistent—such has been the stubbornness from time immemorial. I often observe mediocre scholars, clinging to hollow doctrines, refusing to believe in the most profound truths. Their affliction lies in possessing some cleverness, yet being crippled by bias and constraint, burdening themselves with petty cunning rather than remaining purely in utter darkness, no better than those who cannot tell beans from wheat. With the narrow vision of peering through a tube, they block off all that lies beyond their limited understanding—how is this different from drawing water from a hundred-fathom well with a rope merely a fathom long, unaware of their tool’s inadequacy, and then declaring the well dry? The vulgar hear the roar of fierce winds and raging fires and call it winter thunder; they see drifting clouds moving west and claim the moon races east. Should someone correct them, they refuse to believe or awaken—such is their blind faith in themselves. Those who listen trust their ears without question; those who see trust their eyes without doubt. Yet what they hear and see may well be false. If so, can our ears and eyes truly be trusted? How much more difficult, then, is it to discern the heart’s judgments, which have no form or sound, far surpassing the clarity of sight and hearing? To rely solely on one’s own mind and then dismiss the most distant truths of the world, declaring the Way of immortals mere fiction—is this not the height of delusion?"

The Master of Embracing Simplicity said: "Beauty and ugliness are fixed, yet love and hate differ in nature, so the two eyes do not see alike. Refined and vulgar music are distinct, yet likes and dislikes vary, so the two ears do not hear alike. Truth and falsehood have their essence, yet choices and rejections clash, so the two hearts do not deliberate alike. Some mistake ugliness for beauty, muddy for clear, loss for gain—these three are starkly opposed, plainly evident, so easily discerned, yet they remain irreconcilable. How much less, then, can the subtlest matters of immortality be made universally believable? There is no reason why all should accept them. If everyone were made to understand, what value would there be in the enlightened? To wait for the vulgar to cease their delusions would be like awaiting the Yellow River’s waters to run clear—it would not be long, but it would never come. I cannot remain silent because I hope to guide those who may yet be swayed. As for the unyielding, even the ancients could do nothing with them."

The Master of Embracing Simplicity said: "The difficulty of clarifying the highest truths and the disbelief in immortals are long-standing, not unique to our time. Someone asked: "The human Dao has many paths, and seeking immortality is most difficult. If one does not abandon other affairs, then nothing can be accomplished fully. The pursuit of arts and letters, the burdens of sorrow and joy, the Way of ruler and minister—how can these be set aside?"

The Master Embracing Simplicity replied: "The essential Dao is not burdensome; what matters is that few practice it. The only concern is whether one’s resolve is firm and one’s faith unwavering—why fear the neglect of human affairs? Those of great talent cultivate both simultaneously; what difficulty is there? Within, they treasure the Dao of nurturing life; without, they harmonize with the world. Cultivating the self, the self endures; governing the state, the state attains great peace. They instruct the common scholar with the Six Classics and transmit esoteric arts to those of kindred spirit. If they wish to linger awhile, they remain to aid their age; if they wish to ascend, they soar beyond the clouds—such are the superior scholars. Those who, relying on their own talent and strength, cannot achieve both, abandon worldly affairs to focus solely on the cultivation of virtue—these are of the next rank.

Of old, the Yellow Emperor bore the weight of the Four Seas yet did not hinder his ascent at Mount Dinghu. Peng Zu served as a grandee for eight hundred years before journeying west to the Flowing Sands. Laozi was the Keeper of the Archives, Ning Feng the Pottery Master, Fang Hui the Village Scholar, Lü Wang the Grand Preceptor, Qiu Sheng served in Yin, Ma Dan held office in Jin, Lord Fan subdued Yue and set sail upon the sea, Qin Gao bore the tablet at Song Kang’s court, Chang Sheng humbled himself to hold the whip, and Duke Zhuang concealed his power in a minor post. Many ancients attained the Dao while aiding the world, cultivating it in the midst of courtly reclusion—surely they had strength to spare. Why must one retreat to the mountains and forests, wholly abandoning the affairs of the living, before attaining perfection?

There are also those whose hearts are tranquil and silent, whose natures abhor clamor, who find joy in freedom and sorrow in honor and duty. They gird themselves in hempen robes, eat wild herbs, grasp the plow, delight in their three joys, abide in constancy, await their end, neither scheming for a fleeting life nor fearing a swift death. They decline appointments worth a thousand gold and scorn the rank of minister. Even without cultivating anything, they remain thus—how much more so if they add to this the knowledge of the immortal’s Dao? They would surely refuse to serve the world. Each follows their own aspiration; one cannot speak of them as a single type."

The Master Embracing Simplicity said: "The world values a single good word more than a thousand gold pieces, yet this refers only to the gain or loss of armies and states, or the rightness or wrongness of one’s conduct. As for teaching others the secret of long life or transmitting the method of not dying—this is not merely the good word of an ordinary person. How could it be worth only a thousand gold? If one were gravely ill and on the verge of death, and another saved them, restoring them to health, would this not be called a great kindness and weighty favor? Now, if one follows the immortal classics, flies with the Nine Elixirs, and ingests gold and jade, the whole world could be made deathless—such beneficence is not merely the merit of reviving one person. The virtue of the Yellow Emperor and Laozi is truly boundless, yet none recognize it, dismissing it as wild and absurd talk. How lamentable!"

The Master Embracing Simplicity said: "To seek immortality, one must grasp its essentials. The essentials lie in treasuring essence, circulating qi, and ingesting a single great elixir—no more is needed. Yet these three matters have depths and shallows. Without a enlightened teacher or enduring hardship, one cannot master them hastily.

Though it is said to circulate qi, there are several methods for doing so. Though it is called the bedchamber arts, the techniques therein number over a hundred. Though it is said to ingest elixirs, the formulas for doing so number roughly a thousand. When first teaching others, one begins with the shallow. Only those of steadfast intent and tireless diligence, whose efforts are evident, are then told the essentials.

Thus, circulating qi can cure a hundred illnesses, ward off pestilence, subdue tigers and snakes, stanch wounds and bleeding, allow one to dwell underwater or walk upon it, stave off hunger and thirst, or extend lifespan. Its great essential is embryonic breathing. Those who attain embryonic breathing can refrain from inhaling and exhaling through nose and mouth, as if within the womb—then the Dao is achieved.

When first learning to circulate qi, draw it in through the nose and hold it, silently counting to one hundred twenty in the mind, then exhale gently through the mouth. Both inhalation and exhalation should be so subtle that one’s own ears cannot hear the sound of the breath. Always let the intake be greater than the outflow. Place a goose feather before the nose and mouth; when exhaling, the feather should remain motionless. Gradually increase the count over time, and eventually one may reach a thousand. At a thousand, the old become young again, regaining a day with each passing day.

One should circulate qi only during the time of living qi, not during the time of dead qi. Thus it is said: 'The immortal ingests the six qi.' In a day and night, there are twelve hours. From midnight to noon are the six hours of living qi; from noon to midnight are the six hours of dead qi. Circulating qi during dead qi is of no benefit.

Those skilled in using qi can exhale upon water, causing it to flow backward for several paces; exhale upon fire, and it is extinguished; exhale upon tigers and wolves, and they crouch, unable to move; exhale upon snakes and vipers, and they coil, unable to flee. If another is wounded by blade or weapon, exhaling upon them stanches the blood. If one hears of another bitten by a poisonous creature, though they may not see the person, they can exhale upon their own hand from afar—men exhale upon the left, women upon the right—and though the person be a hundred leagues away, they will immediately recover. For sudden afflictions and acute illnesses, merely swallowing the qi of three nines brings instant relief.

Yet most people are hasty by nature and few can remain tranquil to cultivate the Dao. Another great essential of circulating qi is to avoid overeating, as well as raw vegetables, fatty meats, and rich foods, which make the qi strong and difficult to contain."

Moreover, one must abstain from wrath and anger, for excessive anger disorders the qi, preventing it from overflowing; it may even provoke coughing, so few can master this practice. My ancestor, the Immortal Master, would plunge into the depths of deep pools after heavy drinking or in the scorching heat of summer, remaining submerged for a full day before emerging—this was precisely because he had mastered the art of closing the qi and embryonic breathing.

There are over ten schools of the bedchamber arts: some serve to mend injuries, others to treat various illnesses, some to absorb yin to replenish yang, and others to extend life and prolong years. Yet their essential principle lies solely in the practice of returning essence to replenish the brain. This method is passed down orally from one true adept to another and was never committed to writing. Even those who consume renowned elixirs but remain ignorant of this essential technique will not attain longevity.

One must not entirely sever yin and yang, for without their union, one incurs blockages and obstructions, leading to illness. Thus, those who are secluded, resentful, or deprived of union often fall ill and die young. Yet indulging without restraint also shortens one’s lifespan. Only by attaining harmony through regulated release can one avoid harm. Without the oral transmission of its techniques, not a single practitioner among ten thousand can engage in this without self-injury or ruin. Masters like Xuansuzi, Du Rongcheng, and Pengzu recorded only its superficial aspects, never committing its most crucial elements to paper. Those who seek immortality should diligently pursue this path.

I record these words of my teacher, Master Zheng, to guide future believers in the Dao—this is no baseless conjecture. Yet I myself have not fully mastered its secrets.

Some Daoist practitioners, fixated solely on the arts of union, seek immortality through them while neglecting the great elixir of golden cinnabar—this is utter folly.

*Baopuzi* states: "Of the Daoist texts attributed to the Yellow Emperor and Laozi, only a small portion are genuine; most were composed by later enthusiasts who expanded upon their own limited knowledge, resulting in a mountain of volumes. The ancients were simple and often lacked talent; their discussions of natural principles were incomplete, their evidence unclear, and their expositions of essentials obscure and difficult to grasp. Even when explained, their insights were shallow and insufficient to expound profound teachings, enlighten the perplexed, encourage the aspiring, instruct beginners, reveal the paths of the mysterious and subtle, or trace the origins of fortune and misfortune. Reciting such texts ten thousand times yields no benefit. While one may wish to study broadly, one should carefully select the finest works and focus on them, disregarding those that are irrelevant.

Yet some later learners fail to distinguish the depth of their authors. Upon encountering texts labeled as Daoist, they amass them by the boxful, exhausting their minds in pursuit of their meaning. This is like searching a swallow’s nest for phoenix eggs or dredging a well for eels—no matter how diligent, they seek what is not there, gaining nothing of practical use. They waste their days in vain, enduring fatigue without the slightest benefit. In public life, they neglect their duties; in private, they fail to achieve longevity. Thus, others inevitably point and say, 'They practiced the Dao so diligently yet did not transcend the world—surely there is no method for avoiding death!' Unaware that their pursuit of immortality was like gazing at a river, longing for fish without a net—it is not that the river lacks fish.

The *Five Thousand Characters*, though attributed to Laozi, offers only broad and cursory discussions. It never fully presents its subject from beginning to end, nor provides verifiable methods. Merely reciting this scripture without grasping its essentials is labor in vain—how much more so for lesser texts?

As for works by Wenzi, Zhuangzi, Guan Lingyin, and their ilk, though their writings trace their lineage to the Yellow Emperor and Laozi and uphold the mysterious and subtle, they merely elaborate on general principles without conveying the ultimate teachings. Some even equate life and death, treating existence as forced labor and death as rest—such views are already a thousand *li* removed from the path of immortality. How can they be worthy of study? Their allegories and parables may offer some utility, serving as makeshift remedies in times of need. Yet it is lamentable that later generations of glib, unscrupulous charlatans and dissolute scoundrels have taken Laozi and Zhuangzi as their refuge."

Someone may ask: "In an age governed by sagely wisdom, only the worthy are treasured. If those who study immortality refuse to serve in office, and all pursue the Dao, who will then assist in governance?"

Bao Puzi replied: "Those who abandon the sagely ruler to dwell in the mountains—this is why Chao Fu and Xu You were esteemed as lofty. Those who withdraw from an age of the Dao—this is why Zhuang Bo was held in honor. When the Yellow Emperor ruled all under heaven, his governance could be called perfect, yet Guangcheng shunned him. When Tang Yao possessed the Four Seas, his reign could be called supremely peaceful, yet Wo Quan refused to serve him. Yet the transformative power of virtue was not diminished by this, nor were worthy men lacking.

When Tian Yi overthrew the Xia, Wu Guang bore a stone and cast himself into the river. When King Wu of Zhou destroyed the Shang, Boyi and Shuqi starved on Western Mountain. When Duke Huan of Qi rose to power, Shao Ji reclined in a humble alley. When the Wei dynasty flourished under King Wen, Gan Mu let his hair loose by the Western River. The Four Elders concealed themselves like phoenixes in Shangluo, yet this did not hinder the Han from teeming with scholars. Zhou Dang stood aloof as a unicorn in the forests and marshes, yet this did no harm to Emperor Guangwu’s just rule.

Those whose hearts cannot be swayed by favor or rank, whose aspirations cannot be altered by utmost wealth—who wash their tassels in the Canglang’s waters, neither submitting nor suffering disgrace—who take fragrant groves as their pavilions, towering peaks as their mansions, kingfisher-green orchids as their couches, verdant leaves as their curtains, who wear coarse cloth in place of embroidered robes, and take ferns and beans as fine fare; who will not eat unless they till the soil themselves, nor clothe themselves unless their wives weave; such men appear but rarely in a thousand years. How much rarer still are those who further abandon their kin to the state, forsake their households without a glance, spurn glory and splendor as though discarding footprints, extinguish desire from their hearts, scale soaring peaks alone, and take echoes and shadows as companions in the famous mountains? Inwardly, they gaze upon the realm of formlessness; outwardly, they listen to the depths of perfect stillness. Within the Eight Directions, how many such men could there be? Yet you fear the ruler will lack ministers—is this not an excess of worry?"

chunks.original_text: 或曰：“学仙之士，独洁其身而忘大伦之乱，背世主而有不臣之慢，余恐长生无成功，而罪罟将见及也。 ”抱朴子答曰：“夫北人石户善卷子州，皆大才也，而沈遁放逸，养其浩然，升降不为之亏，大化不为之缺也。 况学仙之士，未必有经国之才，立朝之用，得之不加尘露之益，弃之不觉毫厘之损者乎？ 方今九有同宅，而幽荒来仕，元凯委积，无所用之。 士有待次之滞，官无暂旷之职； 勤久者有迟叙之叹，勋高者有循资之屈； 济济之盛，莫此之美，一介之徒，非所乏也。 昔子晋舍视膳之役，弃储贰之重，而灵王不责之以不孝； 尹生委衿带之职，违式遏之任，而有周不罪之以不忠。 何者，彼诚亮其非轻世薄主，直以所好者异，匹夫之志，有不可移故也。 夫有道之主，含垢善恕，知人心之不可同，出处之各有性，不逼不禁，以崇光大，上无嫌恨之偏心，下有得意之至欢，故能晖声并扬於罔极，贪夫闻风而忸怩也。 吾闻景风起则裘炉息，世道夷则奇士退，今丧乱既平，休牛放马，烽燧灭影，干戈载戢，繁弱既韬，卢鹊将烹，子房出玄帷而反闾巷，信越释甲胄而修鱼钓，况乎学仙之士，万未有一，国家吝此以何为哉？ 然其事在於少思寡欲，其业在於全身久寿，非争竞之丑，无伤俗之负，亦何罪乎？ 且华霍之极大，沧海之滉漾，其高不俟翔埃之来，其深不仰行潦之注，撮壤土不足以减其峻，挹勺水不足以削其广，一世不过有数仙人，何能有损人物之鞅掌乎？ ” 或曰：“果其仙道可求得者，五经何以不载，周孔何以不言，圣人何以不度世，上智何以不长存？ 若周孔不知，则不可为圣。 若知而不学，则是无仙道也。 ”抱朴子答曰：“人生星宿，各有所值，既详之於别篇矣。 子可谓戴盆以仰望，不睹七曜之炳粲； 暂引领於大川，不知重渊之奇怪也。 夫五经所不载者无限矣，周孔所不言者不少矣。 特为吾子略说其万一焉。 虽大笑不可止，局情难卒开，且令子闻其较略焉。 夫天地为物之大者也。 九圣共成易经，足以弥纶阴阳，不可复加也。 今问善易者，周天之度数，四海之广狭，宇宙之相去，凡为几里？ 上何所极，下何所据，及其转动，谁所推引，日月迟疾，九道所乘，昏明修短，七星迭正，五纬盈缩，冠珥薄蚀，四七凌犯，彗孛所出，气矢之异，景老之祥，辰极不动，镇星独东，羲和外景而热，望舒内鉴而寒，天汉仰见为润下之性，涛潮往来有大小之变，五音六属，占喜怒之情，云动气起，含吉凶之候，欃、枪、尤、矢，旬始绛绎，四镇五残，天狗归邪，或以示成，或以正败，明易之生，不能论此也。 以次问春秋四部诗书三礼之家，皆复无以对矣。 皆曰悉正经所不载，唯有巫咸甘公石申海中郄萌七曜记之悉矣。 余将问之曰，此六家之书，是为经典之教乎？ 彼将曰非也。 余又将问曰：甘石之徒，是为圣人乎？ 彼亦曰非也。 然则人生而戴天，诣老履地，而求之於五经之上则无之，索之於周孔之书则不得，今宁可尽以为虚妄乎？ 天地至大，举目所见，犹不能了，况於玄之又玄，妙之极妙者乎？ ”复问俗人曰：“夫乘云茧产之国，肝心不朽之民，巢居穴处，独目三首，马闲狗蹄，修臂交股，黄池无男，穿胸旁口，廪君起石而泛土船，沙壹触木而生群龙，女娲地出，杜宇天堕，甓飞犬言，山徙社移，三军之众，一朝尽化，君子为鹤，小人成沙，女丑倚枯，贰负抱桎，寄居之虫，委甲步肉，二首之蛇，弦之为弓，不灰之木，不热之火，昌蜀之禽，无目之兽，无身之头，无首之体，精卫填海，交让递生，火浣之布，切玉之刀，炎昧吐烈，磨泥漉水，枯灌化形，山夔前跟，石修九首，毕方人面，少千之劾伯率，圣卿之役肃霜，西羌以虎景兴，鲜卑以乘鳖强，林邑以神录王，庸蜀以流尸帝，盐神婴来而虫飞，纵目世变於荆岫，五丁引蛇以倾峻，肉甚振翅於三海。

Some may say: "Those who study the Dao of immortality purify only themselves while neglecting the great ethical bonds, turning their backs on the sovereign with disloyal arrogance. I fear they will fail to achieve longevity and instead bring down the net of punishment upon themselves."

The Master Embracing Simplicity replies: "Consider the northerners Shi Hu, Shan Juan, and Zi Zhou—all men of great talent—who lived in seclusion and freedom, nurturing their vast and unbounded qi. Their rise and fall did not diminish them, nor did the great transformations of the world leave them lacking. How much more so for those who study the Dao of immortality, who may not possess the talent to govern the state or serve in court? Gaining them brings no more benefit than a speck of dust or a drop of dew, while losing them causes no more loss than a hair’s breadth. Today, the Nine Provinces are united under one roof, yet those from distant lands come to serve; men of exceptional ability lie idle in abundance, with no use for them. Scholars wait endlessly for appointments, while offices remain briefly vacant. Those who have labored long sigh at delayed promotions, and those of high merit suffer under rigid seniority. In this flourishing age, so rich in talent, even the humblest are not lacking.

In ancient times, Prince Jin abandoned his duty to attend the royal meals and relinquished his position as heir apparent, yet King Ling did not accuse him of disloyalty. Yin Sheng cast aside his official sash and departed from his post, yet the Zhou dynasty did not condemn him for disloyalty. Why? Because they truly understood that such men were not slighting the world or their rulers, but simply followed their own inclinations—a resolve no ordinary man could sway. A ruler who embodies the Dao harbors tolerance and forgiveness, recognizing that human hearts cannot be the same and that each follows their own nature. Without coercion or prohibition, he fosters greatness, free from personal bias, allowing his subjects the utmost joy in fulfilling their aspirations. Thus, his glory and renown spread boundlessly, and even the greedy, upon hearing of his virtue, feel shame. I have heard that when the balmy winds rise, fur garments and stoves are put away; when the world is at peace, extraordinary men retreat. Now that the chaos of war has settled, oxen are left to rest and horses released, beacon fires vanish like shadows, and weapons are sheathed. The mighty bows are stored away, and even the finest hounds face the pot. Zhang Liang emerged from the imperial tent to return to the streets, while Han Xin and Peng Yue laid down their armor to take up fishing. How much more so for those who study the Dao of immortality, of whom not even one in ten thousand exists? What would the state lose by sparing them?

Moreover, their path lies in reducing thoughts and desires, their practice in preserving the body and prolonging life. They do not engage in vulgar competition, nor do they harm the customs of the world. What crime have they committed? The peaks of Hua and Heng are vast, the blue sea boundless—neither their height awaits the dust of soaring birds, nor their depth relies on the trickle of rainwater. A handful of earth cannot diminish their towering majesty, nor a ladle of water lessen their expanse. Even if there were but a few immortals in an age, how could they disrupt the world’s affairs?"

Some may ask: "If the Dao of immortality can indeed be attained, why do the Five Classics not record it? Why do Zhou and Kong not speak of it? Why did the sages not transcend the world, and why do the wisest not live forever? If Zhou and Kong did not know of it, they cannot be called sages. If they knew but did not pursue it, then the Dao of immortality does not exist."

The Master Embracing Simplicity replies: "The stars under which men are born each have their destined influence, as I have explained in detail elsewhere. You are like one who wears a basin on his head and looks up, unable to see the brilliance of the seven luminaries; or one who briefly cranes his neck toward a great river, unaware of the wonders hidden in its depths. There are countless things the Five Classics do not record, and many truths Zhou and Kong did not speak of. Let me briefly mention but a fraction for you. Though you may laugh uncontrollably and your narrow mind may struggle to open, at least you will hear a rough outline.

Heaven and earth are the greatest of all things. The nine sages together composed the *Book of Changes*, which fully encompasses the workings of yin and yang—nothing more can be added. Yet ask even the most skilled interpreters of the *Changes*: How many *li* span the circumference of the heavens? How wide are the Four Seas? How far apart are the cosmos? Where does the sky end above, and what supports it below? What force sets it in motion? Why do the sun and moon vary in speed, following the nine paths? Why do dawn and dusk differ in length? How do the seven stars take turns governing the seasons? Why do the five planets wax and wane, form halos, or suffer eclipses? What causes the conjunctions of the four and seven stars, the appearance of comets, the omens of celestial arrows, the portents of solar halos? Why does the North Star remain fixed while Saturn moves eastward? Why does the sun’s outer light bring heat, while the moon’s inner reflection brings cold? Why does the Milky Way, though visible above, embody the nature of moisture below? Why do the tides ebb and flow with great and small variations? How do the five notes and six tones reveal the emotions of joy and anger? How do clouds and winds carry signs of fortune and misfortune? What of the celestial spears, banners, and arrows, the red and crimson vapors, the Four Pillars and Five Remnants, the Heavenly Dogs and Returning Demons—some foretelling success, others ruin? Even the *Book of Changes* cannot explain these. If you ask scholars of the *Spring and Autumn Annals*, the *Four Books*, the *Book of Songs*, or the *Three Ritual Classics*, they too will have no answers. They will say these matters are not recorded in the classics, that only Wu Xian, Gan Gong, Shi Shen, Hai Zhong, and Xie Meng’s records of the seven luminaries contain them.

I would then ask: Are these six scholars’ works part of the canonical teachings? They would say no. I would further ask: Are Gan, Shi, and the others sages? They would also say no. Yet men are born beneath the heavens and walk upon the earth, yet seek these truths in the Five Classics in vain, and find nothing in the writings of Zhou and Kong. Should we then dismiss them all as falsehoods? Heaven and earth are vast—even what lies before our eyes remains incomprehensible. How much more so the mysteries beyond mysteries, the subtleties beyond subtleties?"

He further asked the skeptics: "What of the lands where men ride clouds and women give birth to cocoons, where people’s livers and hearts do not decay? What of those who dwell in nests or caves, with single eyes or three heads, horses with human feet or dogs with cloven hooves, arms so long they cross, or legs so entwined they cannot walk? What of the Yellow Pool without men, or those with chests pierced and mouths on their sides? What of Lin Jun, who rose from stone and sailed in a boat of earth, or Sha Yi, who touched wood and gave birth to dragons? What of Nü Wa, who emerged from the earth, or Du Yu, who fell from the heavens? What of the flying tiles, the talking dogs, the shifting mountains, the moving altars? What of the three armies that transformed in a single morning—gentlemen into cranes, commoners into sand? What of Nü Chou, who leaned upon a withered tree, or Er Fu, who bore his shackles? What of the hermit crabs that shed their shells and walked in flesh, or the two-headed snakes that became bowstrings? What of the unburning wood, the unheated fire, the birds of Changshu with no eyes, the beasts with no bodies, the heads without bodies, the bodies without heads? What of Jing Wei, who filled the sea, or the trees that yielded their places in turn? What of the fire-washed cloth, the jade-cutting knives, the flames that spew from darkness, the water filtered from mud? What of the withered trees that revived and took form, or the mountain *kui* that walked ahead? What of the nine-headed *Shixiu*, the human-faced *Bifang*, the *Shaoqian* who subdued the Earl of Wind, the *Shengqing* who commanded the frost? What of the Western Qiang who rose with the tiger’s shadow, or the Xianbei who grew strong by riding turtles? What of Lin Yi, ruled by divine records, or Yong and Shu, whose emperors were floating corpses? What of the Salt God, who summoned insects to fly, or the slant-eyed people who transformed in the Jing Mountains? What of the five Ding who lured the serpent to topple the peaks, or the flesh that sprouted wings over the three seas?"

"Golden tablets and jade-script characters emerged beside the Well of Yu. The true mechanism balanced evenly, carved within the veins of patterned stone. All these marvels number in the thousands—unrecorded in the Five Classics, unspoken by Zhou or Kong. Can one still claim such things do not exist?

As for the southerners who enter pillars and exit through ears, the archer who stilled water in his elbow to draw the bow, Bohun who trod cliffs of ten thousand *ren* yet stood on tiptoe, Lü Liang who walked singing over the abyss, Duke Song who imitated leaves to deceive the eye, Gongshu whose wooden birds soared with dark wings, Li Zhu who discerned the tip of a hair at a hundred paces, Ben and Huo who displayed their strength of ten thousand *jun*, the Yue man who revived the dead with a needle’s touch, Shu Hai who leapt over distances of a thousand *li*, the Ying craftsman who swung his axe at the whitewash on a nose, Zhong Du who bared his body in freezing weather—these are all feats beyond the reach of Zhou or Kong. Can one still deny their existence?

If the sage truly has limits, then it is no wonder he does not attain immortality. Yet not attaining immortality does not diminish his sageliness. chunks.original_text: 抱朴子曰：“道者涵乾括坤，其本无名。 论其无，则影响犹为有焉； 论其有，则万物尚为无焉。 隶首不能计其多少，离朱不能察其仿佛，吴札晋野竭聪，不能寻其音声乎窈冥之内，犭周豨犭步猪疾走，不能迹其兆朕乎宇宙之外。 以言乎迩，则周流秋毫而有馀焉； 以言乎远，则弥纶太虚而不足焉。 为声之声，为响之响，为形之形，为影之影，方者得之而静，员者得之而动，降者得之而俯，升者得之以仰，强名为道，已失其真，况复乃千割百判，亿分万析，使其姓号至於无垠，去道辽辽，不亦远哉？ 俗人不能识其太初之本，而修其流淫之末，人能淡默恬愉，不染不移，养其心以无欲，颐其神以粹素，扫涤诱慕，收之以正，除难求之思，遣害真之累，薄喜怒之邪，灭爱恶之端，则不请福而福来，不禳祸而祸去矣。 何者，命在其中，不系於外，道存乎此，无俟於彼也。 患乎凡夫不能守真，无杜遏之检括，爱嗜好之摇夺，驰骋流遁，有迷无反，情感物而外起，智接事而旁溢，诱於可欲，而天理灭矣，惑乎见闻，而纯一迁矣。 心受制於奢玩，情浊乱於波荡，於是有倾越之灾，有不振之祸，而徒烹宰肥腯，沃酹醪醴，撞金伐革，讴歌踊跃，拜伏稽颡，守请虚坐，求乞福愿，冀其必得，至死不悟，不亦哀哉？ 若乃精灵困於烦扰，荣卫消於役用，煎熬形气，刻削天和，劳逸过度，而碎首以请命，变起膏肓，而祭祷以求痊，当风卧湿，而谢罪於灵祇，饮食失节，而委祸於鬼魅，蕞尔之体，自贻兹患，天地神明，曷能济焉？ 其烹牲罄群，何所补焉？ 夫福非足恭所请也，祸非禋祀所禳也。 若命可以重祷延，疾可以丰祀除，则富姓可以必长生，而贵人可以无疾病也。 夫神不歆非族，鬼不享淫祀，皂隶之巷，不能纡金根之轩，布衣之门，不能动六辔之驾，同为人类，而尊卑两绝，况於天神，缅邈清高，其伦异矣，贵亦极矣。 盖非臭鼠之酒肴，庸民之曲躬，所能感降，亦已明矣。 夫不忠不孝，罪之大恶，积千金之赂，太牢之馔，求令名於明主，释愆责於邦家，以人释人，犹不可得，况年寿难获於令名，笃疾难除於愆责，鬼神异伦，正直是与，冀其曲佑，未有之也。 夫惭德之主，忍诟之臣，犹能赏善不须贷财，罚恶不任私情，必将修绳履墨，不偏不党，岂况鬼神，过此之远，不可以巧言动，不可以饰赂求，断可识矣。 楚之灵王，躬自为巫，靡爱斯牲，而不能却吴师之讨也。 汉之广陵，敬奉李须，倾竭府库而不能救叛逆之诛也。 孝武尤信鬼神，咸秩无文，而不能免五柞之殂。 孙主贵待华乡，封以王爵，而不能延命尽之期。 非牺牲之不博硕，非玉帛之不丰醲，信之非不款，敬之非不重，有丘山之损，无毫厘之益，岂非失之於近，而营之於远乎？ 第五公诛除妖道，而既寿且贵； 宋庐江罢绝山祭，而福禄永终； 文翁破水灵之庙，而身吉民安； 魏武禁淫祀之俗，而洪庆来假，前事不忘，将来之鉴也。 明德惟馨，无忧者寿，啬宝不夭，多惨用老，自然之理，外物何为！ 若养之失和，伐之不解，百痾缘隙而结，荣卫竭而不悟，太牢三牲，曷能济焉？ 俗所谓率皆妖伪，转相诳惑，久而弥甚，既不能修疗病之术，又不能返其大迷，不务药石之救，惟专祝祭之谬，祈祷无已，问卜不倦，巫祝小人，妄说祸祟，疾病危急，唯所不闻，闻辄修为，损费不訾，富室竭其财储，贫人假举倍息，田宅割裂以讫尽，箧柜倒装而无馀。
